heading.title: PART 47 MATTERS ARISING UNDER THE COMMERCIAL ARBITRATION ACT 2010 [rr 47.1–47.20]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 47 MATTERS ARISING UNDER THE COMMERCIAL ARBITRATION ACT 2010 [rr 47.1–47.20]

leg:heading.title: MATTERS ARISING UNDER THE COMMERCIAL ARBITRATION ACT 2010 [rr 47.1–47.20]

p.text: [Pt 47 insrt Amendment 10 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[12], effective 7 July 2006 ; am Amendment 37 of 2010 Sch 1[1], effective 5 October 2010]
Legislation cited in [47.0.0] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 1984.
(CTH) International Arbitration Act 1974.
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 ss 1C, 2A.

The Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 repealed and replaced the Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 on 1 October 2010. The provisions of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 are based upon the UNCITRAL Model Law on International Commercial Arbitration (as adopted by the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law on 21 June 1985 with amendments as adopted by that Commission in 2006).

Australian arbitration law has always been “dualist” — one law for international (Commonwealth) and another for domestic (State). The international arbitration regime is governed by a federal statute, the International Arbitration Act 1974 (Cth) (itself significantly reformed to apply the UNCITRAL Model Law); the domestic arbitration regime in NSW is governed by the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 (NSW). The Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 and similar Acts introduced in other Australian state jurisdictions and the reforms to the International Arbitration Act 1974 (Cth) are intended to narrow the gap between laws applicable to domestic and international arbitration. While in each state there will still be separate statutes for domestic and international arbitration, the intention is to achieve general consistency between the state and federal statutes (all based on the UNCITRAL Model Law).

The paramount object of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010, as set out in ss 1C and 2A , is to facilitate the fair and final resolution of commercial disputes by impartial arbitral tribunals without unnecessary delay or expense. Section 2A requires the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 (NSW) to be interpreted in a manner consistent with the International Arbitration Act 1974 (Cth) (thus expertise developed under one regime can be applied under the other). NSW courts are bound to supervise arbitrations in a manner that is consistent with the paramount objectives.
The conduct or arbitral proceedings (Pt 5) under the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 differs from that under the Commercial Arbitration Act 1984:
individuals without legal qualifications are expressly permitted to represent parties at the hearing of commercial dispute: s 24A(2)
the tribunal may appoint one or more experts to report to it on specific issues and may compel parties to provide evidence to the expert: s 26
a right of appeal is only available if both parties agree or opt-in: s 34A
reduction in the circumstances where court intervention can be sought: ss 34–34A
removes the court’s discretion on whether to stay legal proceedings where there is a valid arbitration agreement
widens the powers available to arbitrators (arbitrators can order discovery, security for costs, issue a subpoena); arbitrators have the power to order interim relief and specific performance

NSW courts no longer have a discretion as to whether to enforce an agreement to arbitrate. On the application of a party to an arbitration agreement, the court must stay any court proceedings begun in breach of an arbitration; s 8 agreement unless the agreement is “null and void, inoperative or incapable of being performed”: s 8.

row.entry: This Division sets out the general rules governing applications arising out of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 (NSW).
This Division governs the making, acceptance, withdrawal, execution, disclosure and compliance with offers of compromise in arbitration proceedings.

This Part applies to proceedings in the Supreme Court and where the arbitration agreement so provides, to some types of District Court and Local Court proceedings: see Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 ss 2(1) (definition of “the court”), 6 .
The rules in this Part of the UCPR are based on the former SCR Pt 72A. The rules are virtually identical with the former SCR Pt 72A.
Entry into the Commercial Arbitration List ‥ [r 47.8]

p.text: [Div 1 subst Amendment 37 of 2010 Sch 1[2], effective 5 October 2010]
In this Part:
has the same meaning as it has in the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 .
has the same meaning as it has in the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010.
means the Supreme Court or a court exercising functions under section 6(2) of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 .
Legislation cited in [47.1.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 s 6.

If an arbitration agreement provides (or the parties have otherwise agreed in writing) that the District Court or the Local Court has jurisdiction under the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 , then either of these courts may perform the functions of arbitration assistance and supervision specified in s 6 of the Act as required.

Practice Note SC Eq 9 sets out the case management procedures for the Commercial Arbitration List to facilitate the prompt resolution of disputes arising in the context of arbitral proceedings in which the Supreme Court has jurisdiction whether by virtue of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010, the provision of an arbitration agreement or otherwise. The objective is to provide parties with a quick and effective mechanism for resolving disputes in relation to arbitration agreements or which may arise in the context or out of arbitral proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 47.2] r 47.2 Preliminary point of law (cf SCR Part 72A, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Preliminary point of law (cf SCR Part 72A, rule 3)

p.text: An application to the court for a determination under section 27J of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 must be made within 14 days after the date on which the consent of the arbitral tribunal or the consents of all other parties have been obtained.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 47.3] r 47.3 Time for applications and appeals (cf SCR Part 72A, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Time for applications and appeals (cf SCR Part 72A, rule 5)

p.text: An application made to the Court pursuant to section 34 of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 must include:
a statement by the applicant as to the date that the party received the award, or
if a request has been made under section 33 of that Act, the date on which that request was disposed of by the arbitral tribunal.

If a party appeals on a question of law arising out of an award and the parties have agreed before the end of the appeal period specified in section 34A(6) of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 that an appeal may be made under section 34A(1) , the originating process for the appeal is to contain a statement:
providing the date (or dates if there are more than two parties) that such agreement was reached, and
identifying the question of law, and
describing the nature of the dispute with sufficient particularity for an understanding as to the context in which the question of law arises under section 34A(3) and (4), and
specifying the respects in which it is asserted that the arbitral tribunal fell into error.
If a party seeks leave to appeal on a question of law arising out of an award, the originating process for the application for leave is to contain a statement of the party’s case:
providing the dates relevant to the calculation of the appeal period specified in section 34A(6) of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010, and
describing the nature of the case with sufficient particularity for an understanding of the matters referred to in the statement, and
identifying the question of law, and
specifying how the determination of the question will substantially affect the rights of one or more of the parties, and
specifying that the question is one which the arbitral tribunal was asked to determine, and
specifying the reasons for which it is asserted that, on the basis of the findings of fact in the award:
the decision of the tribunal on the question is obviously wrong, or
the question is one of general public importance and the decision is at least open to serious doubt, and
specifying the reasons for which, despite the agreement of the parties to resolve the matter by arbitration, it is just and proper in all the circumstances for the court to determine the question.

The appeal period is 3 months after the proposed appellant receives a copy of the arbitral award or any subsequent clarification or correction of the award: see Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 s 34A(6).
Part 33 applies to the issue of a subpoena under section 27A of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 in the same way as it applies to the issue of a subpoena in proceedings in the court.
A subpoena for production before an arbitral tribunal may, with the leave of the court or the arbitral tribunal, require production on any day.

Unless the court otherwise orders, a subpoena requiring production of any document or thing before an arbitral tribunal must permit the person named, instead of attending and producing it before the arbitral tribunal, to produce the document or thing:
to a person, and at a place, nominated in writing by the arbitral tribunal and stated in the subpoena, and
by hand or by post,
so that the person nominated receives it not later than 2 days before the first date on which production before the arbitral tribunal is required.
If a document or thing is produced in accordance with subrule (3) the person nominated:
if required to do so, must give a receipt to the person producing the document or thing, and
must produce the document or thing as the nature of the case requires or as the arbitral tribunal may direct.
Subrule (3) does not apply to so much of a subpoena as requires a person to attend to give evidence.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 47.5] r 47.5 Court assistance in taking evidence (cf SCR Part 72A, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Court assistance in taking evidence (cf SCR Part 72A, rule 8)

p.text: This rule applies where a request for assistance of the court is made by an arbitral tribunal or party to an arbitration with the approval of an arbitral tribunal.
Rule 24.3 applies to an arbitration under the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 in the same way as it applies to proceedings in the court.
If any order is made pursuant to rule 24.3 as so applied, the other provisions of Part 24 apply as if:
a reference in that Part to proceedings included a reference to the arbitration proceedings, and
the provisions of rule 24.14(4), (5) and (6) were omitted.
Unless the court otherwise orders, the examiner must send the transcript of evidence, any document that constitutes an audio-visual recording and the exhibits to the registrar.
On receiving the transcript of evidence, the registrar must file it in the proceedings on the examination.

The court may make orders for the transmission to the arbitral tribunal of the transcript of evidence, document, any exhibit or copy of any exhibit and any such transcript, document, exhibit or copy is taken to have been taken or received (as the case requires) in the course of the arbitration proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 47.6] r 47.6 Application to enforce award (cf SCR Part 72A, rule 9)

leg:heading.title: Application to enforce award (cf SCR Part 72A, rule 9)

p.text: An application to the court under section 35 of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 must join the party who seeks enforcement of the award as plaintiff and the party against whom the enforcement is sought as defendant.

Section 9 of the International Arbitration Act 1974 of the Commonwealth applies to proceedings in which a person seeks leave under section 35 of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 to enforce an award in the same way as it applies to proceedings in which a person seeks the enforcement of a foreign award by virtue of the Commonwealth Act.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 47.7] r 47.7 Leave to appeal (cf SCR Part 72A, rule 10)

leg:heading.title: Leave to appeal (cf SCR Part 72A, rule 10)

p.text: An appeal does not lie from a direction or decision in proceedings in the court under the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 except by leave of the court to which the appeal is to be made.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 47.8] r 47.8 Method of entry into the Commercial Arbitration List

leg:heading.title: Method of entry into the Commercial Arbitration List

p.text: An application made to the court pursuant to the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 (including an application for an interim measure pursuant to section 17J of that Act) and the rules is to be made by summons and entered in the Commercial Arbitration List in the manner specified in the Commercial Arbitration List Practice Note as amended from time to time.
See Practice Note SC Eq 9 Commercial Arbitration List (see esp paras 10–14).
